stream_context.summary: Kaze continues integrating and polishing a factory/power-plant level ("Oily Body May") recently remade by Biobak: importing assets, adding lighting, implementing moving sparkle effects along wires, and working through a to-do list of gameplay/visual fixes (fuzzy visuals, decal color changes, ledge safe-position softlock, and a special elevator camera). He also outlines near-term schedule: boss area next, then factory effects, then returning to the ice castle level.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete progress on a major level integration (Biobak remake), several actionable bugfixes/engine tweaks (sparkle path math, prim-color decal changes, elevator camera), and a clear short-term roadmap (finish boss/factory this weekend, return to ice castle next week).

findings.summary: The factory/power-plant level is structured with multiple distinct sub-areas (including an underground section and an office), and Kaze highlights the underground area as his favorite so far.
Biobak delivered a full remake of the level layout/assets that Kaze is now importing and wiring up; some remaining assets are still pending from Biobak.
The level is "very low on memory," constraining what extra props/decor can be added (Kaze declines adding additional “scales” due to memory limits).
Kaze is working around a known, permanent rendering issue: a Glideon plugin bug prevents a lighting effect from correctly lighting each ball individually, and he considers it unfixable on their end.
Kaze observes intermittent severe breakage in an underground area (music/animations failing) that he suspects is caused by broken ROM pointers/DMA behavior.
findings.quote: It looks like some of the ROM pointers break. Which breaks the music and the animations. Like the DMA is just broken.

findings.summary: A sparkle/“electric line” effect was mispositioning debug visuals (cloned Marios) due to incorrect math; Kaze identifies the root cause (missing a square-root step) and fixes it without extensive retesting.
findings.quote: I forgot the SQR, okay now it works. I'm not even gonna test if it works, I just know it works.

findings.summary: The level includes an interactive “fuzzy” hazard (touching it makes Mario dizzy), and Kaze is actively tuning the look/feel because the fuzzy currently “does not look fuzzy.”

A specific visual requirement is implemented: when Mario hits the fuzzy, the prim color on certain edge decals (ocean edge and NPG) must change; Kaze fixes an apparent non-reset issue that turned out to be caused by forgetting to export the updated level.

Upgrading to Blender 4.x introduced workflow regressions; Kaze struggles to sample exact vertex colors/hex values and relies on chat-discovered workarounds (flat + vertex display mode, etc.) to retrieve precise color values for N64 materials.
findings.quote: Oh, yeah, we're on the new Blender 4 and I am not a fan of it. They messed up some important things.

findings.summary: Kaze is addressing a softlock risk by changing logic so Mario’s “safe position” is not updated while hanging from a ledge; he cannot reliably reproduce the bug and resorts to code inspection and defensive fixes.

A special, hard-positioned elevator camera is added; Kaze uses a sentinel value (32767) to represent “unset,” and adjusts camera offsets to reduce clipping and prevent players getting stuck in awkward positions.

Kaze decides falling into oil should not instantly kill the player; instead he prefers a less punishing respawn with reduced health, and he considers an “oil decal” overlay on Mario that fades over a few seconds to communicate the hazard.
findings.quote: I don't want that to be that punishing for no reason, you know.

findings.summary: Kaze outlines planned collectible logic: collecting five special coins will award a bonus star, and he’s considering unlocking a radar after collecting around three of them (final thresholds not decided).

Kaze closes by setting a concrete near-term roadmap: next stream(s) focus on the boss area and remaining factory effects; he aims to finish the factory work over the weekend, then return to the ice castle level they’ve been stuck on.

biobak.summary: Biobak remade the factory/power-plant level, providing assets and layout that Kaze imported and is now implementing; additional assets are still expected.
Biobak clarifies effect intent: the current sparkles are “star sparkles,” not electrical sparkles, influencing how Kaze frames/labels the visual effect work.
biobak.quote: These are star sparkles, not electrical sparkles.

biobak.summary: Biobak helps diagnose an art import mismatch by identifying that the fan model shown in-game wasn’t Biobak’s; Kaze locates and swaps to the correct turbine asset.
Biobak flags Kaze’s Internet Explorer taskbar icon as a joke ("porn shortcut"), showing casual rapport but no direct dev impact.
Biobak pitches an easter egg: a janitor NPC “throwing soap out of the cage,” talkable, using Biobak-written text.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears briefly in chat; Kaze jokes that clothing shrink/fit issues could be from Zeina washing clothes too warm, hinting at their day-to-day domestic overlap with dev life.

key_stories.title: Sparkle path effect breaks due to missing math step
key_stories.summary: While implementing sparkles that move along overhead lines, Kaze uses floating Mario clones as debug markers and finds they cluster in the wrong place, implying the effect is reading the wrong waypoint/position. After narrowing it down, he realizes the distance calculation was wrong due to a missing square-root.
key_stories.challenge: Sparkle actors/debug markers move toward incorrect waypoints and appear in nonsensical positions, threatening a key visual setpiece.
key_stories.process: Kaze isolates the issue by disabling most instances, adds prints, checks waypoint math, and audits the distance computation.
key_stories.outcome: Fix applied by restoring the missing SQR step; the markers slide correctly along the intended line path.
key_stories.key_quote: I forgot the SQR, okay now it works.

key_stories.title: Fuzzy/decal color change appears broken until level export
key_stories.summary: Kaze works on an effect where hitting the fuzzy should change prim colors on certain edge decals. He initially sees incorrect colors and non-reset behavior (orange tint persists), even in menus, and suspects shader/material logic issues.
key_stories.challenge: Color changes don’t reset as expected, making the fuzzy feedback effect look wrong and potentially confusing.
key_stories.process: He validates vertex/prim color sampling via Blender 4 workarounds, compares behavior across elements that use “the exact same math,” then tests in a more accurate emulator and checks the asset pipeline.
key_stories.outcome: Root cause was a simple pipeline miss: he hadn’t exported the updated level. After exporting, the effect resets correctly.
key_stories.key_quote: Yep, I just had to export a level.

key_stories.title: Preventing a ledge-hang softlock by freezing Mario’s safe position
key_stories.summary: A bug sometimes leaves Mario unable to respawn properly after edge-hanging interactions, effectively softlocking the player. Kaze can’t reliably reproduce it, so he decides to implement a defensive fix.
key_stories.challenge: Softlock reports/possibility without clear reproduction steps; risk of shipping a game-breaking edge case.
key_stories.process: He attempts to recreate the bug in-level, then switches to code inspection and implements a rule: do not update Mario’s “safe position” while hanging from ledges, and considers additional safety constraints.
key_stories.outcome: Fix is queued/implemented as part of the changelog-driven to-do list, reducing risk even without full repro.

key_stories.title: Elevator experience polish: special camera and anti-stuck adjustments
key_stories.summary: The elevator segment needs better presentation and fewer camera/collision edge cases. Kaze adds a special camera and then notices jumping/clipping issues and awkward viewpoints.
key_stories.challenge: Camera can clip into geometry and players can get stuck or lose readability inside the elevator; elevator floor collision is described as a known complicated bug.
key_stories.process: He adds a hard-positioned camera, uses a sentinel value (32767) for “not set,” pushes the camera forward, and proposes a subtle collision-map offset (move collision inward by ~4 units) to prevent getting into bad positions.
key_stories.outcome: Special elevator camera is marked done; further collision fixes are deferred as complex, but mitigations are planned.
key_stories.key_quote: So what I'm gonna do is... we're just gonna move it in for units.
